Description: A terracotta flask with a flattened circular body decorated in relief: on each side is a border of egg-and-dart patterns. At the centre is a small rosette from which long angular-tipped petals extend to the border. The vessel is complete with its neck and flaring mouth. On each side of the neck is a handle with a bolster lower spring. Two non-functional feet are placed at the bottom. Two-piece mould. Dark-grey Nile silt with some mica, covered with a black slip (Memphis Black Ware).
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired at Saqqara. Ptolemaic, late third to second century BC. Comparanda: Close: Petrie et al. 1910: pl. xxxvii:59, from Memphis, 'from a factory north-east of the glazing kilns'. Near: My´sliwiec and Bakr Said 1999: 197, fig 14a, from pottery workshops at Athribis: context second century bc; Petrie Museum uc47627; Van Ingen 1933: pl. ii:18, dated first to second century AD; Weber 1914: no. 477, a plaster mould from the Fayum. Bibliog: Seif el-Din 2006: pl. 11:4, no. 56.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3650)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
